data.note: The regulatory framework is fairly simple in terms of applying for a license, and the holder of the license may then sell-on to transmission and distribution companies. All projects larger than 100kW are required to receive a licence from ZERA, but the process is relatively simple. There is no specific legislation pertaining to mini grids, but from what developers have said, it is not hard to set up.
data.name: Mini-grids: licensing

data.note: There is no evidence of such concessions to date.
data.name: Mini-grids: concessions

data.note: There is currently no limit on the size of projects in the regulatory framework.
data.name: Mini-grids: threshold

data.note: Zimbabwe Energy Regulatory Authority is charged with managing the electricity and fuels sector.
data.name: Dedicated regulator

data.note: The utility has a business development and planning department which IPPs would deal with.
data.name: Dedicated team within utility

data.note: To receive a generating license is relatively simple. The forms for it are standardised but there are no real examples for mini grids.
data.name: Light-handed regulatory framework

data.note: Developers of mini grids have been able to set up their own tariffs and business models to run the grids, and need to have them approved by the regulator.
data.name: Cost reflective tariffs

data.note: While there are limited examples in Zimbabwe, PPAs do include long-term price agreements. There has been difficulty in negotiating a reliable rate with the regulator.
data.name: Stable tariff guaranteed

data.note: The organisations that are running mini grids in the country have been able to use their own business models for the projects. The only real examples are NGOs that generally work hand-in-hand with REA.
data.name: Tariff deregulation

data.note: No documents regarding structured PPAs exist.
data.name: Standardised PPAs

data.note: From conversations with multiple developers, PPAs are meant to be of sufficient duration to be bankable.  For example, ZPC issued 300MW of solar tenders for a 20-year period.  Nonetheless, there are no examples of existing/operational PPAs of such length.
data.name: PPAs of sufficient duration

data.note: Only projects that have signed a PPA with ZETDC are able to sell to the utility.
data.name: Purchase obligation

data.note: There are no clear precedents as to what will happen when the grid arrives.
data.name: Clear rules on interconnection

data.note: Owners of mini grids will be required to negotiate an offtake agreement with ZETDC to sell their power into the grid but there are currently no examples of this happening. Mini grid expansion is a tenet of Zimbabwe's INDC commitments, but no coordinated effort currently exists to regulate these en masse.
data.name: Clear rules on arrival of the main grid

data.note: There is currently no forthcoming documentation on planned grid extensions.
data.name: Transparent grid extension plan

data.note: While projects need to go through the licensing procedure laid out by ZERA, there are no set standards that developers have to comply with.
data.name: Quality of service standards

data.note: One IPP is currently exploring issuing a bond for grid-scale solar development, with regulator approval, but no examples of banking services exist.
data.name: SPPs can deliver financial services

data.note: Since 2002 a programme has been in place and two components exist within it: these are the expanded rural electrification programme and the electricity end-use infrastructure development programme.  The programme appears to be inactive as of 2016 due to inadequate funding, but its original coal was to electrify 10389 institutions countrywide.  As of 2011, 6424 institutions , or 62%, were electrified.
data.name: Rural electrification program

data.note: The Zimbabwe Rural Electrification Authority.
data.name: Rural electrification agency

data.note: Zimbabwe is working toward universal access to clean energy by 2030 under its National Energy Policy implementation strategy from 2012. No progress updates have been set out as of late.
data.name: Energy access targets (general)

data.note: As part of Zimbabwe's INDC, $3bn is being allocated toward solar powered off-grid installations over the next 15 years.
data.name: Offgrid energy access target

data.note: All schools, clinics, government offices and chief homesteads receive a 100% subsidy while other programmes receive a 60% subsidy but households do not receive a subsidy.
data.name: Connection grants

data.note: There are tax incentives on offer for infrastructure projects but they need to be over $500,000 and have a local ownership exceeding 51%.
data.name: Other off-grid incentives

data.note: Solar Access, a division of TeleAccess Zimbabwe, offers PAYG access for Azuri Technologies solar products.
data.name: PAYG availability

data.note: Solar products receive import duty exemptions, although stakeholders feel the laws are outdated and importers don't receive full benefit.
data.name: Import duty reductions

data.note: The sector is seeing steady growth due to import duty exemptions, although the quality is on the low side, and the majority of consumers can't afford high-cost renewable systems.  No other import-related barriers exist.
data.name: Other import barriers

data.note: No other barriers or business licensing requirements were discovered to prevent the retail of off-grid solar products.  These can be purchased anywhere from a developer for custom solutions, to a big-box department store off the shelf.
data.name: Other retail barriers
